title: MLB GPP Pivots: Tuesday 9/3
text:
Welcome to the MLB GPP Pivots article, where we’ll be looking to uncover some sneaky-good DFS plays away from the popular lifts. These recommendations are usually risk/reward commodities meant to be used in large-field tournaments. Typically, blending these low-owned hidden gems with well-aligned staples contributes to a viable GPP strategy.

Keep in mind that the following player write-ups were constructed earlier in the day, and sometimes injury/rest situations can alter the fantasy landscape. Monitoring our MLB News & Headlines Feed throughout the day will keep you in the loop while giving you the subsequent DFS consequences of each information piece.

We will be looking at the 12-game main slate beginning at 7:05 ET.

Scroll to continue with content Ad

PITCHER

Sandy Alcantara - Miami (at Pittsburgh)

Alcantara hasn’t been as sharp through the second half of the season, but he’s beginning to right the ship with three quality starts over his last four outings. The Miami righty is a sleeper candidate to post a respectable fantasy return on his bargain-basement salary within tonight’s slate. The matchup at Pittsburgh looks encouraging, as the Pirates rank below average in most major hitting categories. The pitcher-friendly atmosphere of PNC Park doesn’t hurt either.

CATCHER / FIRST BASE

Miguel Cabrera - Detroit (at Kansas City)

A good share of DFS enthusiasts will consider Kansas City LHP Mike Montgomery against this lowly Tigers’ offense. However, we can’t forget about Cabrera, who is swinging a confident bat with five hits, one homer, three runs, and two RBIs over his past three games. The future Hall-of-Famer could jump on the platoon advantage in this battle of veteran players.

SECOND BASE

Gavin Lux - LA Dodgers (vs. Colorado)

Story continues

Lux made quite the impression in his major league debut yesterday, going 2-5 with a double and three runs. He could rack up more production tonight, assuming he’s granted another start. The matchup looks great against Colorado RHP Chi Chi Gonzalez, who carries a vulnerable .441 wOBA split to left-handed bats. The rookie’s near-minimum salary blends very favorably into all lineup formats as well.

THIRD BASE

Kyle Seager - Seattle (at Chicago Cubs)

Most people will shy away from the lefty/lefty matchup here, but Cubs’ LHP Jon Lester owns an inflated .359 wOBA split to left-handed bats over the past two seasons. Seager has a strong history against the Chicago southpaw, making him an interesting GPP Pivot away from the popular third baseman. Seager has been a fantasy beast over the past month, and he certainly carries a fair amount of upside in his back pocket.

SHORTSTOP

Adalberto Mondesi - Kansas City (vs. Detroit)

I’m hoping most people forgot about this guy, as Mondesi has been on the shelf since July 16. He made his return yesterday with a sweet 4-5 showing with two runs and three steals. Mondesi can contribute in every category (hits, homers, runs, RBIs, steals), presenting massive fantasy upside on any given night. The matchup is definitely favorable against Detroit LHP Daniel Norris and a patchwork Tigers’ bullpen.

OUTFIELD

Khris Davis - Oakland (vs. LA Angels)

Davis is having a down season, and most people have probably written him off for fantasy purposes. However, I’m viewing this as a nice buy-low opportunity for the Oakland slugger, as he’ll step into a promising draw against Angels’ RHP Jaime Barria’s .372 wOBA split to right-handed bats. He came back nicely from a small break (paternity leave) with a 2-3 performance yesterday in New York. Perhaps some of that momentum will carry into this favorable matchup.

Tommy Edman - St. Louis (vs. San Francisco)

Edman is no stranger to this column, and I really like him as a sleeper outfielder tonight. San Francisco RHP Dereck Rodriguez has really struggled lately, allowing 11 earned runs and 14 hits through nine innings over his last two starts. There’s a good chance those problems will persist while facing a red-hot St. Louis team on the road. The rookie switch-hitter, Edman, is an affordable option within that. There’s certainly upside in his profile after registering a trio of three-hit performances over his last eight games.
